DADOS-GERAIS.NOME-EM-CITACOES-BIBLIOGRAFICAS: VIEIRA, L.E.A.;VIEIRA, L.A.;Vieira, Luis E. A.;VIEIRA, LUIS;VIEIRA, L.E.

RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH: Possui graduao em Fsica pela Universidade Federal de Santa Maria (1995), mestrado (1998) e doutorado (2002) em Geofsica Espacial pelo Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas Espaciais, ps-doutorado pelo Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas Espaciais (2006) e pelo Max-Planck-Institut fr Sonnensystemforschung (2009). Atuou como pesquisador do Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique (CNRS/Frana) de 2009 Agosto/2012. Tem experincia na rea de Astronomia, com nfase em Fsica Solar, atuando principalmente nos seguintes temas: simulaes MHD do dnamo solar, modelagem da irradincia solar durante o Holoceno, modelagem do campo magntico solar, acoplamento energtico vento solar - magnetosferas planetrias, previso de tempestades magnticas, e efeitos da variabilidade solar no clima terrestre.
RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH-EN: bachelor's at Fisica from Universidade Federal de Santa Maria (1995), master's at Geophysics from Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas Espaciais (1998) and doctorate at Geophysics from Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas Espaciais (2002). Has experience in Astronomy, focusing on Solar Physics, acting on the following subjects: solar irradiance, solar surface magnetic field, solar euv emission, thermosphere and atmospheric processes.

POS-DOUTORADO.NOME-AGENCIA: Fundao de Amparo Pesquisa do Estado de So Paulo

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Estudo das Inter-Relaes Sol-Terra-Clima Por Meio de Registros Observacionais e Naturais.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: Descrio: A pesquisa desenvolvida habitualmente sobre as relaes Sol-Terra-Clima realizada principalmente pela aquisio e anlise de dados observacionais numa escala de tempo que vai do passado recente ao presente. Entre os dados observacionais mais usados, podem ser citados: as manchas solares, dados geomagnticos e ionosfricos, dados meteorolgicos, climticos e hidrolgicos. Por outro lado, pode-se apreender sobre o passado da variabilidade solar e climtica pela leitura de arquivos terrestres que nos fornecem dados "proxy" (substitutos) da histria do Sol e do clima. Tendo em mente que diferentes mecanismos naturais podem afetar o clima de um dado lugar, em adio a efeitos antropognicos, pretende-se estudar a influncia da atividade solar, eventos El Nio, entre outros fenmenos geofsicos, na variabilidade do clima. Pretende-se estudar as relaes Sol-Terra-Clima atravs da anlise matemtica de sries temporais de registros ambientais (anis de crescimento de rvores e outros registros naturais) e observacionais (manchas solares; dados climticos...), visando o aumento de conhecimento sobre as interaes e fenmenos envolvidos (atividade solar; vulcanismo; eventos El Nio etc.) e de previsibilidade das conseqncias que podem afetar as atividades humanas.

INTEGRANTES-DO-PROJETO.NOME-PARA-CITACAO: VIEIRA, L.E.A.;VIEIRA, L.A.;Vieira, Luis E. A.;VIEIRA, LUIS;VIEIRA, L.E.

FINANCIADOR-DO-PROJETO.NOME-INSTITUICAO: Fundao de Amparo Pesquisa do Estado de So Paulo

ATUACAO-PROFISSIONAL.NOME-INSTITUICAO: Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique

VINCULOS.OUTRAS-INFORMACOES:
ENCERRAMENTO em 31 de Agosto de 2012 (Anno Domini).
Participao no ?European Commission's Seventh Framework Programme (FP7/2007-2013)?. Projetos nos. 218816 (Projeto SOTERIA) e 261948 (Projeto ATMOP).
European Commission's Seventh Framework Programme (FP7/2007-2013) under the grant agreement no. 218816 (SOTERIA project) and 261948 (ATMOP Project). Period: 09/2009 to 08/2012.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: The ATMOP research project aims at building a new thermosphere model with the potential to spawn an operational version. It will enable precise air drag computation which is mandatory for improved survey and precise tracking of space objects in Low Earth Orbit and the initiation of appropriate measures to minimise risks to satellites (track loss, collisions) and ground assets (re-entry zone). The state of the thermosphere can vary rapidly and significantly in response to solar and geomagnetic activity (space weather), i.e., accurate orbit prediction requires accurate space-time nowcast and forecast of the thermosphere. Despite the presence in Europe of one of the three groups that have the capability to develop and maintain an operational semi-empirical thermosphere model (CNES/CNRS, the other two are in the US), and of one of the world leading teams in the field of physical modelling of the atmosphere (UCL), Europe has currently neither a near-real-time thermosphere prediction model nor operational services to provide regular thermosphere nowcast and forecast. The ATMOP project is designed to fill this gap through: Defining and assessing new proxies to describe the external forcing of the thermosphere; Developing an advanced semi-empirical Drag Temperature Model (DTM) that meets the requirements for operational orbit computations; Improving physical modelling of the thermosphere to assist the development of the advanced DTM and of a global physical model with data assimilation capabilities which may ultimately become the successor to semi-empirical models; and Developing schemes for near-real-time assimilation of thermospheric and ionospheric data into an advanced predictive DTM and into the physical Coupled Middle Atmosphere-Thermosphere (CMAT2) model. ATMOP therefore contributes to ensuring the security of space assets from space weather events (SPA.2010.2.3-01) and the development of the European capability to reduce dependence of space operations on the US.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: The ATMOP research project aims at building a new thermosphere model with the potential to spawn an operational version. It will enable precise air drag computation which is mandatory for improved survey and precise tracking of space objects in Low Earth Orbit and the initiation of appropriate measures to minimise risks to satellites (track loss, collisions) and ground assets (re-entry zone). The state of the thermosphere can vary rapidly and significantly in response to solar and geomagnetic activity (space weather), i.e., accurate orbit prediction requires accurate space-time nowcast and forecast of the thermosphere. Despite the presence in Europe of one of the three groups that have the capability to develop and maintain an operational semi-empirical thermosphere model (CNES/CNRS, the other two are in the US), and of one of the world leading teams in the field of physical modelling of the atmosphere (UCL), Europe has currently neither a near-real-time thermosphere prediction model nor operational services to provide regular thermosphere nowcast and forecast. The ATMOP project is designed to fill this gap through: Defining and assessing new proxies to describe the external forcing of the thermosphere; Developing an advanced semi-empirical Drag Temperature Model (DTM) that meets the requirements for operational orbit computations; Improving physical modelling of the thermosphere to assist the development of the advanced DTM and of a global physical model with data assimilation capabilities which may ultimately become the successor to semi-empirical models; and Developing schemes for near-real-time assimilation of thermospheric and ionospheric data into an advanced predictive DTM and into the physical Coupled Middle Atmosphere-Thermosphere (CMAT2) model. ATMOP therefore contributes to ensuring the security of space assets from space weather events (SPA.2010.2.3-01) and the development of the European capability to reduce dependence of space operations on the US.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: SOTERIA aims at creating a wide synergy in the fields of solar-space and geo-physics among different centers in a number of European countries to achieve a higher level of quality and accessibility for the observational data and for the models. Our goal is to help creating the basis for a deeper understanding of solar and space processes having terrestrial impact. See: http://soteria-space.eu/

Our goal is to help creating the basis for a deeper understanding of solar and space processes having terrestrial impact. See: http://soteria-space.eu/

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Edital CNPq 19/2004 (Universal) - 2005-2007, Ref. 472396/2004-8, Projeto: Previso e estudo do clima espacial
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: O projeto de Previso e Estudo do Clima Espacial tem por objetivo estudar a variabilidade do Clima Espacial, desde suas origens solares, at seus efeitos no Geoespao vizinho Terra. Para tanto, faz-se necessrio um estudo acerca da dinmica das ejees coronais de massa, no Sol, durante sua propagao no meio interplanetrio, e nas vizinhanas da Terra, atravs de observaes combinadas de diversos instrumentos, tanto de superfcie, quanto espaciais. Sero utilizadas observaes dos instrumentos LASCO C2 e C3, e do instrumento EIT, todos a bordo do satlite SOHO, que consistem em imagens de alta resoluo que necessitam de processamento computacional para extrao das informaes que se pretende obter, tais como observao de estruturas que se movem em uma seqncia de imagens, medida de suas velocidades. Pretende-se tambm construir instrumentao prpria, como por exemplo magnetmetros tipo "fluxgate" para acompanhamento das variaes do Campo Geomagntico durante Tempestades Geomagnticas. Essas informaes sero utilizadas para melhoria dos modelos de previso de ocorrncia de Tempestades Geomagnticas e da variabilidade do Clima Espacial. Para tanto, uma infra-estrutura computacional potente se faz necessria, com capacidade de processamento grfico eficiente, bem como uma infra-estrutura bsica laboratorial para construo de instrumentao de baixo custo. O projeto de pesquisa tambm possui um aspecto aplicado, que consiste em um acompanhamento em tempo real da atividade solar, que ser feito atravs de um computador dedicado, ligado a central de distribuio de imagens do satlite SOHO e de dados dos satlites monitores do vento solar vizinho Terra, atravs da internet, o qual mostrar as observaes dos satlites em tempo real e permitir fazer boletins de previso da possvel ocorrncia de distrbios geomagnticos, de maneira muito semelhante ao que se faz nas previses meteorolgicas.

INTEGRANTES-DO-PROJETO.NOME-PARA-CITACAO: VIEIRA, L.E.A.;VIEIRA, L.A.;Vieira, Luis E. A.;VIEIRA, LUIS;VIEIRA, L.E.

FINANCIADOR-DO-PROJETO.NOME-INSTITUICAO: Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Cientfico e Tecnolgico

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Solar Telescope for Helioseismology and Surface Magnetic Fields Observations
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: The solar electromagnetic and corpuscular emissions are strongly modulated by the evolution of the magnetic structure of the solar atmosphere, which is imprinted in the solar surface. The evolution of the magnetic structure leads to gradual changes of the solar activity (space climate) as well as violent events (space weather) that affect the whole heliosphere. In particular, the solar output affects the ionized and neutral components of the Earth?s atmosphere that have direct impact on human activities from agriculture to high-technological systems. The solar magnetism is driven by the energy transport from the inner layers of the solar structure to the solar atmosphere. Although systematic observations have revealed several features related to the evolution of the solar activity, there is not a complete explanation of the physical processes that lead to the solar activity cyclic variability and its long-term changes. Here we propose to develop a magnetograph and visible-light imager instrument to study the solar dynamo processes through observations of the solar surface magnetic field distribution. The instrument will provide measurements of the vector magnetic field and of the line-of-sight velocity in the solar photosphere. As the magnetic field anchored at the solar surface produces most of the structures and energetic events in the upper solar atmosphere and significantly influences the heliosphere, the development of this instrument plays an important role in reaching the scientific goals of The Atmospheric and Space Science Coordination (CEA) at the Brazilian National Institute for Space Research (INPE). In particular, the CEA?s space weather program will benefit most from the development of this technology. Additionally, we expect that this project will be the starting point to establish a strong research program on helioseismology/astroseismology that could benefit the three divisions of the CEA. The proposed instrument will be designed to operate on ground, but flexible enough to be adapted to operate on balloon and space-based platforms. In this way, our main aim is acquiring progressively know-how to build state-of-art solar vector magnetograph and visible-light imagers for space-based platforms to contribute to the efforts of the solar-terrestrial physics community to address the main unanswered question on how our nearby Star works.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: The solar electromagnetic and corpuscular emissions are strongly modulated by the evolution of the magnetic structure of the solar atmosphere, which is imprinted in the solar surface. The evolution of the magnetic structure leads to gradual changes of the solar activity (space climate) as well as violent events (space weather) that affect the whole heliosphere. In particular, the solar output affects the ionized and neutral components of the Earth?s atmosphere that have direct impact on human activities from agriculture to high-technological systems. The solar magnetism is driven by the energy transport from the inner layers of the solar structure to the solar atmosphere. Although systematic observations have revealed several features related to the evolution of the solar activity, there is not a complete explanation of the physical processes that lead to the solar activity cyclic variability and its long-term changes. Here we propose to develop a magnetograph and visible-light imager instrument to study the solar dynamo processes through observations of the solar surface magnetic field distribution. The instrument will provide measurements of the vector magnetic field and of the line-of-sight velocity in the solar photosphere. As the magnetic field anchored at the solar surface produces most of the structures and energetic events in the upper solar atmosphere and significantly influences the heliosphere, the development of this instrument plays an important role in reaching the scientific goals of The Atmospheric and Space Science Coordination (CEA) at the Brazilian National Institute for Space Research (INPE). In particular, the CEA?s space weather program will benefit most from the development of this technology. Additionally, we expect that this project will be the starting point to establish a strong research program on helioseismology/astroseismology that could benefit the three divisions of the CEA. The proposed instrument will be designed to operate on ground, but flexible enough to be adapted to operate on balloon and space-based platforms. In this way, our main aim is acquiring progressively know-how to build state-of-art solar vector magnetograph and visible-light imagers for space-based platforms to contribute to the efforts of the solar-terrestrial physics community to address the main unanswered question on how our nearby Star works.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Solar Telescope for Helioseismology and Surface Magnetic Fields Observations

INTEGRANTES-DO-PROJETO.NOME-PARA-CITACAO: VIEIRA, L.E.A.;VIEIRA, L.A.;Vieira, Luis E. A.;VIEIRA, LUIS;VIEIRA, L.E.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: The total solar irradiance (TSI) is a key parameter to understand the long-term evolution of the Earth?s climate and to untangle the contributions from natural and anthropogenic drivers. The main challenge measuring the solar irradiance is the calibration of the instrument and its long-term degradation. Ground-based observations are highly affected by the radiative transfer through the atmosphere and its variability. Alternatively, measurements of the TSI can also be made employing instruments onboard of space platforms. Although the effects from the Earth?s atmosphere are eliminated, the same problems regarding the instrument calibration and stability are observed in space-based instruments. In this context, we are conceptually developing a broadband radiometer based on the ATMEGA 328 Chipset. The prototype of the instrument is designed to operate on ground, but flexible enough to be adapted to operate in balloon and small artificial satellites.

INTEGRANTES-DO-PROJETO.NOME-PARA-CITACAO: VIEIRA, L.E.A.;VIEIRA, L.A.;Vieira, Luis E. A.;VIEIRA, LUIS;VIEIRA, L.E.

ATUACAO-PROFISSIONAL.NOME-INSTITUICAO: Journal of Atmospheric and Solar-Terrestrial Physics

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Climate And Weather of the Sun-Earth System - CAWSES/Germany
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: The German science foundation (Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft, DFG) has announced a priority program for CAWSES in July 2004. Most topics of the international CAWSES program are covered. Several institutions submitted proposals in the framework of this program. A review panel meeting took place in Walberberg (close to Cologne) and 24 proposals were accepted. A total of 18 different institutions all over Germany are now involved in CAWSES related projects. Nine post doctoral fellows and 30 PhD positions are funded within the priority program and approximately 3 Million Euros per year are available. In the first round these projects will run for 2 years. Two more successive periods with 2 years each are planned, i.e., the program runs for 6 years from 2005 to 2011. Although the German priority program on CAWSES funds activities at German institutions only, international collaboration is strongly encouraged. (see http://www.bu.edu/cawses/germany.html)

About this Journal Dataset Papers in Geosciences is a peer-reviewed, open access journal devoted to the publication of dataset papers in all areas of geosciences.
Dataset Papers in Geosciences is part of Datasets International, a series of journals devoted to the dissemination of Dataset Papers covering a wide range of academic disciplines. In addition to publishing Dataset Papers, Datasets International hosts the underlying data that is associated with these papers and makes it accessible to all researchers worldwide.
http://www.datasets.com/journals/geosciences/
